tgt_text.0: DECIMUS JUNIUS JUVENALIS, 1 the author of the following Satires, was born at Aquinum, an inconsiderable town of the Volsci, about the year of Christ 38.2
tgt_text.1: He was either the son, or the foster-son, of a wealthy freedman, who gave him a liberal education.
tgt_text.2: From the period of his birth, till he had attained the age of forty, nothing more is known of him than that he continued to perfect himself in the study of eloquence, by declaiming, according to the practice of those days ;
tgt_text.3: yet more for his own amusement, than from any intention to prepare himself either for the schools or the courts of law.
tgt_text.4: About this time he seems to have discovered his true bent, and be­ taken himself to poetry.
tgt_text.5: Domitian was now at the head of the government, and showed symptoms of reviving that system of favouritism which had nearly ruined the empire under Claudius, by his unbounded partiality for a young pantomime dancer of the name of Paris.
tgt_text.6: Against this minion, Juvenal seems to have directed the first shafts of that satire which was destined to make the most powerful vices tremble, and shake .
tgt_text.7: the masters of the world on their thrones.
tgt_text.8: He composed a few lines1 on the influence of Paris, with considerable success, which encouraged him to cultivate this kind of poetry :
tgt_text.9: he had the prudence, however, not to trust himself to an auditory, in a reign which swarmed with informers ;
tgt_text.10: and his compositions were, therefore, secretly handed about amongst his friends.
tgt_text.13: and, having made many large additions to his first sketch, or perhaps re-cast it, produced what is now called his Seventh Satire, which he recited to a numerous assemblage.
tgt_text.14: The consequences were such as he had probably anticipated:
tgt_text.15: Paris, informed of the part which he bore in it, was seriously offended, and complained to the emperor, who, as the old account has it, sent the author, by an easy kind of punishment, into Egypt with a military com­ mand.
tgt_text.16: To remove such a man from his court must undoubt­ edly have been desirable to Domitian ;
tgt_text.17: and, as he was spoken of with kindness in the same Satire, which is entirely free from political allusions, the " facetiousness " of the punishment (though Domitian's was not a facetious reign) renders the fact not altogether improbable.
tgt_text.18: Yet, when we consider that these reflections on Paris could scarcely have been published before LXXXIV., and that the favourite was disgraced and put to death almost immediately after, we shall be inclined to doubt whether his banishment actually took place;
tgt_text.19: or, if it did, whether it was of any long duration.
tgt_text.20: That Juvenal was in Egypt is certain ;
tgt_text.21: but he might have gone there from motives of personal safety, or, as Salmasius has it, of curiosity.
tgt_text.22: How­ ever this may be, it does not appear that he was ever long absent from Rome, where a thousand internal marks clearly show that all his Satires were written.
tgt_text.23: But whatever punish­ ment might have followed the complaint of Paris, 1 it had no other effect on our author, than that of increasing his hatred of tyranny, and turning his indignation upon the emperor himself, whose hypocrisy, cruelty, and licentiousness, became, from that period, the object of his keenest reprobation.
tgt_text.24: He profited, indeed, so far by his danger or his punishment, as to recite no more in public;
tgt_text.25: but he continued to write during the remainder of Domitian's reign, in which he finished, as I conceive, his second, third,1 fifth, sixth,2 apd perhaps thir- teenth1 Satires ;
tgt_text.26: the eighth2 I have always looked upon as his first.
tgt_text.27: In xcv., when Juvenal was in his 54th year, Domitian ban­ ished the philosophers from Rome, and soon after from Italy, with many circumstances of cruelty;
tgt_text.28: an action, for which, I am sorry to observe, he is covertly praised by Quintilian.
tgt_text.29: Though Juvenal, strictly speaking, did not come under the description of a philosopher, yet, like the hare in the fable, he might not unreasonably entertain some apprehensions for his safety, and, with many other persons eminent for learning and virtue, judge it prudent to withdraw from the city.
tgt_text.30: To this period I have always inclined to fix his journey to Egypt.
tgt_text.31: Two years afterwards the world was happily relieved from the tyranny of Domitian;
tgt_text.32: and Nerva, who succeeded him, recalled the exiles.
tgt_text.33: From this time there remains little doubt of Juvenal's being at Rome, where he continued his studies in tranquillity.
tgt_text.34: His first Satire after the death of Domitian, seems to have been what is now called the fourth.
tgt_text.35: About this time, too, he probably thought of revising and publishing those which he had already written ;
tgt_text.36: and composed or completed that intro­ ductory piece,' which now stands at the head of his works.
tgt_text.37: As the order is every where broken in upon, it is utterly im­ possible to arrange them chronologically;
tgt_text.38: but I am inclined to think that the eleventh Satire closed his poetical career.
tgt_text.40: but in this he speaks of himself as an old man, " Nostra bibat vernum contracta cuticula solem and indeed he had now passed his grand climacteric.
tgt_text.41: This is all that can be collected of the life of Juvenal;
tgt_text.42: and how much of this is built upon uncertainties !
tgt_text.43: I hope, how­ ever, that it bears the stamp of probability;
tgt_text.44: which is all I contend for;
tgt_text.45: and which, indeed, if I do not deceive myself, is somewhat more than can be affirmed of what has been hitherto delivered on the subject.
tgt_text.46: Little is known of Juvenal's circumstances;
tgt_text.47: but, happily, that little is authentic, as it comes from himself.
tgt_text.49: The dignity of poetry is never disgraced in him, as it is in some of his contemporaries, by fretful complaints of poverty, or clamorous whinings for meat and clothes :
tgt_text.50: -the little patrimony which his foster-father left him, he never diminished, and probably never increased.
tgt_text.51: It seems to have equalled all his wants, and, as far as appears, all his wishes.
tgt_text.52: Once only he regrets the narrowness of his fortune ;
tgt_text.53: but the occasion does him honour ;
tgt_text.54: it is solely because he cannot afford a more costly sacrifice to express his pious gratitude for the preservation of his friend:
tgt_text.55: yet " two lambs and a youthful steer " bespeak the affluence of a philosopher;
tgt_text.56: which is not belied by the entertainment provided for his friend Persicus, in that beautiful Satire which is here called the last of his works.
tgt_text.57: Further it is useless to seek :
tgt_text.58: from pride or modesty, he has left no other notices of himself;
tgt_text.60: Horace and Persius, his immediate predecessors, are never weary of speaking of themselves.
tgt_text.61: The life of the former might be written, from his own materials, with all the mi­ nuteness of a contemporary history:
tgt_text.62: and the latter, who attained to little more than a third of Juvenal's age, has left nothing to be desired on the only topics which could interest posterity,-his parent, his preceptor, and his course of studies.
tgt_text.63: IT will now be expected from me, perhaps, to say something on the nature and design of Satire ;
tgt_text.64: but in truth this has so frequently been done, that it seems, at present, to have as little of novelty as of utility to recommend it.
tgt_text.65: Dryden, who had diligently studied the French critics, drew up from their remarks, assisted by a cursory perusal of what Casaubon, Heinsius, Rigaltius, and Scaliger had written on the subject, an account of the rise and progress of dramatic and satiric poetry amongst the Romans ;
tgt_text.66: which he prefixed to his translation of Juvenal.
tgt_text.67: What Dryden knew, he told in a manner that renders every attempt to recount it after him equally hopeless and vain ;
tgt_text.68: but his acquaintance with works of literature was not very extensive, while his reliance on his own powers sometimes betrayed him into inaccuracies, to which the influence of his name gives a dangerous importance."
tgt_text.69: The comparison of Horace with Juvenal and Persius," which makes a principal part of his Essay, is not formed with much niceness of discrimination, or accuracy of judgment.
tgt_text.70: To speak my mind, I do not think that he clearly perceived or fully understood the characters of the first two :
tgt_text.71: -of Persius indeed he had an intimate knowledge ;
tgt_text.72: for, though he certain­ ly deemed too humbly of his poetry, he yet speaks of his beau­ ties and defects in a manner which evinces a more than com­ mon acquaintance with both.
tgt_text.73: What Dryden left imperfect has been filled up in a great measure by Dusaulx, in the preliminary discourse to his trans­ lation of Juvenal, and by Ruperti, in his critical Essay " De diversa Satirarum Lucil.
tgt_text.76: "With the assistance of the former of these I shall endeavour to give a more extended view of the characteristic excellencies and defects of the rival Satirists than has yet appeared in our language;
tgt_text.77: little solicitous for the praise of originality, if I may be allowed to aspire to that of candour and truth.
tgt_text.78: Pre­ viously to this, however, it will be necessary to say something on the supposed origin of Satire:
tgt_text.79: and, as this is a very beaten subject, I shall discuss it as briefly as possible.
tgt_text.80: It is probable that the first metrical compositions of the Ro­ mans, like those of every other people, were pious effusions for favours received or expected from the gods :
tgt_text.81: of these, the earliest, according to Varro, were the hymns to Mars, which, though used by the Salii in the Augustan age, were no longer intelligible.,
tgt_text.82: To these succeeded the Fescennine verses, which were sung, or rather recited, after the vintage and harvest, and appear to have been little more than rude praises of the tutelar'divinities of the country, intermixed with clownish jeers and sarcasms, extemporally poured out by the rustics in some kind of measure, and indifferently directed at the audi­ ence, or at one another.
tgt_text.83: These, by degrees, assumed the form of a dialogue;
tgt_text.84: of which, as nature is every where the same, and the progress of refinement but little varied, some resem­ blance may perhaps be found in the grosser eclogues of Theo­ critus.
tgt_text.85: Thus improved, (if the word may be allowed of such bar­ barous amusements,) they formed, for near three centuries, the delight of that nation :
tgt_text.86: popular favour, however, had a dan­ gerous effect on the performers, whose licentiousness dege­ nerated at length into such wild invective, that it was found necessary to restrain it by a positive law:
tgt_text.87: " Si qui populo occentassit, carmenve condisit, quod infamiam faxit ftagitium­ ve alteri, fuste ferito."
tgt_text.88: From this time we hear no further complaints of the Fescennine verses, which continued to charm the Romans ;
tgt_text.89: until, about a century afterwards, and during the ravages of a dreadful pestilence, the senate, as the histo­ rians say, in order to propitiate the gods, called a troop of players from Tuscany, to assist at the celebration of their ancient festivals.
tgt_text.90: This was a wise and a salutary measure :
tgt_text.91: the plague had spread dejection through the city, which was thus rendered more obnoxious to its fury ;
tgt_text.92: and it therefore be­ came necessary, by novel and extraordinary amusements, to divert the attention of the people from the melancholy objects around them.
tgt_text.93: As the Romans were unacquainted with the language of Tuscany, the players, Livy tells us, omitted the modulation and the words, and confined themselves solely to gestures, which were accompanied by the flute.
tgt_text.94: This imperfect exhi­ bition, however, was so superior to their own, that the Romans eagerly strove to attain the art;
tgt_text.95: and, as soon as they could imitate what they admired, graced their rustic measures with music and dancing.
tgt_text.96: By degrees they dropped the Fescennine verses for something of a more regular kind, which now took the name of SATIRE.
tgt_text.98: These Satires (for as yet they had but little claim to the title of dramas) continued, without much alteration, to the year 514, when Livius Andronicus, a Greek by birth, and a freed­ man of L. Salinator, who was undoubtedly acquainted with the old comedy of his country, produced a regular play.
tgt_text.99: That it pleased cannot be doubted, for it surpassed the Satires, even in their improved state ;
tgt_text.100: and, indeed, banished them for some time from the scene.
tgt_text.101: They had, however, taken too strong a hold of the affections of the people to be easily forgotten, and it was therefore found necessary to reproduce and join them to the plays of Andronicus, (the superiority of which could not be contested,) under the name of Exodia or After-pieces.
tgt_text.102: These partook, in a certain degree, of the general amelioration of the stage ;
tgt_text.103: something like a story was now introduced into them, which, though frequently indecent and always extrava­ gant, created a greater degree of interest than the reciprocation of gross humour and scurrility in unconnected dialogues.
tgt_text.104: Whether any of the old people still regretted this sophisti­ cation of their early amusements, it is not easy to say ;
tgt_text.105: but Ennius, who came to Rome about twenty years after this period, and who was more than half a Grecian, conceived that he should perform an acceptable service by reviving the ancient Satires.
tgt_text.107: He did not pretend to restore them to the stage, for which indeed the new pieces were infinitely better calcu­ lated, but endeavoured to adapt them to the closet, by refining their grossness and softening their asperity.
tgt_text.109: Satire, thus freed from action, and formed into a poem, became a favourite pursuit, and was cultivated by several writers of eminence.
tgt_text.110: In imitation of his model, Ennius confined himself to no particular species of verse, nor indeed of language, for he mingled Greek expressions with his Latin at pleasure.
tgt_text.111: It is solely with a reference to this new attempt that Horace and Quintilian are to be understood, when they claim for the Romans the invention 2 of this kind of poetry ;
tgt_text.112: and certainly they had opportunities of judging which we have not, for little of Ennius, and nothing of the old Satire, remains.
tgt_text.113: It is not necessary to pursue the history of Satire further in this place, or to speak of another species of it, the Varro­ nian, or, as Varro himself called it, the Menippean, which branched out from the former, and was a medley of prose and verse:
tgt_text.114: it will be a more pleasing, as well as a more useful employ, to enter a little into what Dryden, I know not for what reason, calls the most difficult part of his undertaking­ " a comparative view of the Satirists not certainly with the design of depressing one at the expense of another, (for though I have translated Juvenal, I have no quarrel with Horace and Persius,) but for the purpose of pointing out the characteristic excellencies and defects of them all.
tgt_text.115: To do this the more effectually, it will be previously necessary to take a cursory view of the times in which their respective works were pro­ duced.
tgt_text.116: LUCILIUS, to whom Horace, forgetting what he had said in another place, attributes the invention of Satire, flourished in the interval between the siege of Carthage and the defeat of the Cimbri and Teutons, by Marius.
tgt_text.117: He lived therefore in an age in which the struggle between the old and new manners, though daily becoming more equal, or rather inclining to the worse side, was still far from being decided.
tgt_text.118: The freedom of speaking and writing was yet unchecked by fear, or by any law more precise than that which, as has been already men­ tioned, was introduced to restrain the coarse ebullitions of rustic malignity.
tgt_text.119: Add to this, that Lucilius was of a most respectable family, (he was great-uncle to Pompey,) and lived in habits of intimacy with the chiefs of the republic, with Laelius, Scipio, and others, who were well able to protect him from the Lupi and Mutii of the day, had they attempted, which they probably did not, to silence or molest him.
tgt_text.120: Hence that boldness of satirizing the vicious by name, which startled Horace, and on which Juvenal and Persius delight to felici­ tate him.
tgt_text.121: Too little remains of Lucilius, to enable us to judge of his manner:
tgt_text.122: his style seems, however, to bear fewer marks of delicacy than of strength, and his strictures appear harsh and violent.
tgt_text.123: With all this, he must have been an extraordinary man ;
tgt_text.124: since Horace, who is evidently hurt by his reputation, can say nothing worse of his compositions than that they are careless and hasty, and that if he had lived at a more refined period, he would have partaken of the general amelioration.
tgt_text.125: I do not remember to have heard it observed, but I suspect that there was something of political spleen in the excessive popu­ larity of Lucilius under Augustus, and something of courtly complacency in the attempt of Horace to counteract it.
tgt_text.126: Au­ gustus enlarged the law of the twelve tables respecting libels ;
tgt_text.127: and the people, who found themselves thus abridged of the liberty of satirizing the great by name, might not improbably seek to avenge themselves, by an overstrained attachment to the works of a man who, living, as they would insinuate, in better times, practised without fear, what he enjoyed without restraint.
tgt_text.128: The space between Horace and his predecessor, was a dreadful interval " filled up with horror all, and big with death."
tgt_text.129: Luxury and a long train of vices, which followed the immense wealth incessantly poured in from the conquered provinces, sapped the foundations of the republic, which were finally shaken to pieces by the civil wars, the perpetual dic­ tatorship of Cæsar, and the second triumvirate, which threw the Roman world, without a hope of escape, into the power of an individual.
tgt_text.130: Augustus, whose sword was yet reeking with the best blood of the state, now that submission left him no pretence for fur­ ther cruelty, was desirous of enjoying in tranquillity the fruits of his guilt.
tgt_text.131: He displayed, therefore, a magnificence hitherto unknown ;
tgt_text.132: and his example, which was followed by his min­ isters, quickly spread among the people, who were not very unwilling to exchange the agitation and terror of successive proscriptions, for the security and quiet of undisputed des­ potism.
tgt_text.133: Tiberius had other views, and other methods of accomplish­ ing them.
tgt_text.134: He did not indeed put an actual stop to the elegant institutions of his predecessor, but he surveyed them with silent contempt, and they rapidly degenerated.
tgt_text.135: The race of informers multiplied with dreadful celerity;
tgt_text.136: and danger, which could only be averted by complying with a caprice not always easy to discover, created an abject disposition, fitted for the recep­ tion of the grossest vices, and eminently favourable to the designs of the emperor ;
tgt_text.137: which were to procure, by universal depravation, that submission which Augustus sought to obtain by the blandishments of luxury and the arts.
tgt_text.138: From this gloomy and suspicious tyrant, the empire was transferred to a profligate madman.
tgt_text.139: It can scarcely be told without indignation, that when the sword of Chærea had freed the earth from his disgraceful sway, the senate had not suf­ ficient virtue to resume the rights of which they had been deprived ;
tgt_text.140: but, after a timid debate, delivered up the state to a pedantic dotard, incapable of governing himself.
tgt_text.141: To the vices of his predecessors, Nero added a frivolity which rendered his reign at once odious and contemptible.
tgt_text.142: Depravity could reach no further, but misery might yet be extended.
tgt_text.143: This was fully experienced through the turbulent and murderous usurpations of Galba, Otho, and Vitellius;
tgt_text.144: when the accession of Vespasian and Titus gave the groaning world a temporary respite.
tgt_text.145: To these succeeded Domitian, whose crimes form the sub­ ject of many a melancholy page in the ensuing work, and need not therefore be dwelt on here.
tgt_text.146: Under him, every trace of ancient manners was obliterated;
tgt_text.147: liberty was unknown, Jaw openly trampled upon, and, while the national rites were either neglected or contemned, a base and blind superstition took possession of the enfeebled and distempered mind.
tgt_text.149: Nerva, and Trajan, and Hadrian, and the Antonines, restored the Romans to safety and tran­ quillity ;
tgt_text.150: but they could do no more;
tgt_text.151: liberty and virtue were gone for ever:
tgt_text.152: and after a short period of comparative happi­ ness, which they scarcely appear to have deserved, and which brought with it no amelioration of mind, no return of the ancient modesty and frugality, they were finally resigned to destruction.
tgt_text.153: I now proceed to the " comparative view " of which I have already spoken:
tgt_text.154: as the subject has been so often treated, little of novelty can be expected from it ;
tgt_text.155: to read, compare, and judge, is almost all that remains.
tgt_text.156: HORACE, who was gay, and lively, and gentle, and affec­ tionate, seems fitted for the period in which he wrote.

tgt_text.415: When I took up this author, I knew not of any other trans­ lator ;
tgt_text.416: nor was it until the scheme of publishing him was started, that I began to reflect seriously on the nature of what I had undertaken, to consider by what exertions I could ren­ der that useful which was originally meant to amuse, and justify, in some measure, the partiality of my benefactors.
tgt_text.417: My first object was to become as familiar as possible with my author, of whom I collected every edition that my own interest, or that of my friends, could procure ;
tgt_text.418: together with such translations as I could discover either here or abroad:
tgt_text.419: from a careful examination of all these, I formed the plan, to which, while I adapted my former labours, I anxiously strove to accommodate my succeeding ones.

tgt_text.429: With the Greeks and Romans it was still worse:

tgt_text.431: Add to this, that their mythology, and sacred rites, which took their rise in very remote periods, abounded in the undisguised phrases of a rude and simple age, and being religiously handed down from generation to gener­ ation, gave a currency to many terms, which offered no vio­ lence to modesty, though abstractedly considered by people of a different language and manners, they appear pregnant with turpitude and guilt.

tgt_text.477: have spoken where I should be silent, and been prolix where I should be brief:

tgt_text.3615: This Satire, as well as the tenth Satire of Juvenal, is based upon the Second Alcibiades of Plato, which it closely resembles in arrangement as well as sentiment.
tgt_text.3616: The object is the same in all three;
tgt_text.3617: to set before us the real opinion which all good and worthy men entertained, even in the days of Pagan blindness, of the manner and spirit in which the deity is to be approached by prayer and sacrifice, and holds up to reprobation and ridicule the grovelling and low-minded notions whieh the vulgar herd, besotted by ignorance and blinded by self-interest, hold on the subject.
tgt_text.3618: While we admire the logical subtlety with which Plato leads us to a necessary acknowledgment of the justiee of his view, and the thoroughly practical philosophy by which Ju­ venal would divert men from indulging in prayers dictated by mere self- interest, we must allow Persius the high praise of having compressed the whole subject with a masterly hand into a few vivid and comprehensive sentences.
tgt_text.3619: The Satire consists of three parts.
tgt_text.3620: The first is merely an introduction to the subject.
tgt_text.3621: Taking advantage of the custom prevalent among the Ro­ mans of offering prayers and victims, and receiving presents and con­ gratulatory addresses from their friends, on their birth-day, Persius sends a poetical present to his friend Plotius Macrinus, with some hints on the true nature of prayer.
tgt_text.3622: He at the same time compliments him on his superiority to the mass of mankind, and especially to those of his own rank, in the view he took of the subject.
tgt_text.3623: In the second part he exposes the vulgar errors and prejudices respecting prayer and sacrifice, and shows that prayers usually offered are wrong, 1st, as to their matter, and 2ndly, as to their manner :
tgt_text.3624: that they originate in low and sordid views of self-interest and avarice, in ignorant supersti­ tion, or the cravings of an inordinate vanity.
tgt_text.3625: At the same time he holds up to scorn the folly of those who offer up costly prayers, the fulfilment of which they themselves render impossible, by indulging in vicious and depraved habits, utterly incompatible with the requests they prefer.
tgt_text.3626: Lastly, he explains the origin of these sordid and worse than useless prayers.
tgt_text.3627: They arise from the impious and mistaken notions formed by men who, vainly imagining that the Deity is even such a one as them­ selves, endeavour to propitiate his favour in the same grovelling spirit, and with the same unworthy offerings with which they would bribe the good-will of one weak and depraved as themselves;
tgt_text.3628: as though, in Plato's words, an ἐμπορικὴ, τὲΧνη had been established between themselves and heaven.
tgt_text.3629: The whole concludes with a sublime passage, describing in language almost approaching the dignity of inspired wisdom, the state of heart and moral feeling necessary to insure a favourable answer to prayers preferred at the throne of heaven.

tgt_text.3712: The opening scene of the Satire presents us with the bed-chamber where one of these young noblemen, accompanied by some other youths pro­ bably of inferior birth and station, is indulging in sleep many hours after the sun has risen upon the earth.
tgt_text.3713: The entrance of the tutor, who is a pro­ fessor of the Stoical philosophy, disturbs their slumbers, and the confusion consequent upon his rebuke, and the thin disguise of their ill-assumed zeal, is graphically described.
tgt_text.3714: After a passionate outburst of contempt at their paltry excuses, the tutor points out the irretrievable evils that will result from their allowing the golden hours of youth to pass by unim­ proved :
tgt_text.3715: overthrows all objections which are raised as to their position in life, and competency of means rendering such vigorous application super- fluous ;
tgt_text.3716: and in a passage of solemn warning, full of majesty and power, describes the unavailing remorse which will assuredly hereafter visit those who have so far quitted the rugged path that leads to virtue's heights, that all return is hopeless.

tgt_text.3863: —The Satire naturally and readily divides itself into three parts.
tgt_text.3864: In the first he ridicules the misplaced ambition of those who covet exalted station, and aspire to take the lead in state affairs, without possessing those qualifications of talent, education, and experience, which alone could fit them to take the helm of government;
tgt_text.3865: and who hold that the adventitious privileges of high birth and ancient lineage can countervail the enervating effects of luxurious indolence and vicious self-indulgence.
tgt_text.3866: The second division of the subject turns on the much-neglected duty of self-examina­ tion ;
tgt_text.3867: and enforces the duty of uprightness and purity of conduct from the consideration, that while it is hopeless in all to escape the keen scrutiny that all men exercise in their neighbour's failings, while they are at the same time utterly blind to their own defects, yet that men of high rank and station must necessarily provoke the more searching criticism, in ex­ act proportion to the elevation of their position.
tgt_text.3868: He points out also the policy of checking all tendency to satirize the weakness of others, to which Nero was greatly prone, and in fact had already aspired to the dignity of a writer of Satire;

tgt_text.3943: It is, in fact, the earnest expression of unbounded affection for his tutor and early friend Annæus Cornutus, from whom he had imbibed those principles of philosophy, which it is the object of the latter part of the Satire to elucidate.
tgt_text.3944: After a few lines of ridicule at the hackneyed pro­ logues of the day, he puts into the mouth of Cornutus that just criticism of poetical composition which there is very little doubt Persius had in re­ ality derived from his master;
tgt_text.3945: and in answer to this, he takes occasion to profess his sincere and deep-seated love and gratitude towards the pre­ ceptor, whose kind care had rescued him from the vicious courses to which a young and ardent temperament was leading him;
tgt_text.3946: and whose sound judgment and dexterous management had weaned him from the tempta­ tions that assail the young, by making him his own companion in those studies which expanded his intellect while they rectified the obliquity (to use the Stoics' phrase) of his moral character.

tgt_text.4145: —Persius begins with a warm encomium on the genius and learning of his friend Cæsius Bassus, the lyric poet;

tgt_text.4149: A prompt and liberal regard to the necessities and distresses of others is then inculcated;

tgt_text.4151: He then proceeds with great severity and bitter sarcasm to expose the shallow artifices of those who attempt to disguise their sordid selfish­ ness under the specious pretence of a proper prudence, a reverence for the ancient simplicity and frugality of manners, and a proper regard for the interests of those who are to succeed to our inheritance.

tgt_text.4245: ”THE occasion of the following Satire is generally known as " the expulsion of the philosophers from Rome by Domitian.”

tgt_text.4263: With regard to the philosophers, it appears that the followers of the Stoic school were those against whom the edict was especially directed.

tgt_text.4377: Velleius Paterculus, (ii. 29,) on the other hand, says that Lucilia, the mother of Pompey, was daughter of the brother of Lucilius, and of senatorian family.
tgt_text.4378: His birth-place was Suessa, now Sessa, capital of the Aurunci, in Campania;
tgt_text.4379: hence Juvenal (Sat. i. 19) says, " Cur tamen hoc potius libeat decurrere campo, per quern magnus equos Auruncæ flexit alumnus, Si vacat et placidi rationem admittitis edam ;
tgt_text.4380: " and Auso­ nius, (Ep. xv.,) " Rudes Camænas qui Suessæ prævenis.”
tgt_text.4381: At the age of fifteen, B. C. 134, he accompanied his patron, L. Scipio Afri­ canus Æmilianus, to the Numantine war, where he is said to have served as eqnes.
tgt_text.4383: Pat. ii. 9, 4. Here he met with Marius, now about in his twenty-third year, and the young Jugurtha ;
tgt_text.4384: who were also serving under Africanus, and learning, as Velleius says, “ that art of war, which they were afterwards to employ against each other."
tgt_text.4385: In the following year Numantia was taken and razed to the ground, and Lucilius returned with his patron to Rome, shortly after the sedition and death of Tiberius Gracchus;
tgt_text.4386: and lived on terms of the most familiar friendship with him and C. Læ­ lius, until the death of Scipio, B. c. 129;
tgt_text.4387: and even at that early age had already acquired the reputation of a distinguished Satirist.
tgt_text.4388: According to Pighius, (in Tabulis,) he held the office of quæstor, B. c. 127, two years after Scipio's death, and the prætorship, a. c. 117.
tgt_text.4389: Van Heusde is also of opinion that he acted as publicanus;
tgt_text.4390: and from a passage in Cicero, (de Orat. ii. 70,) some suppose he kept large flocks of sheep on the Ager publicus.
tgt_text.4391: Besides Africanus and Lælius, (with whose father-in-law Crassus, however, he was not on very good terms, vid. Cic. de Or. i. 16,) he is said to have enjoyed the friendship of the following distinguished men, Sp. Al­ binus, L. Ælius Stilo, Q. Vectius, Archelaus, P. Philocomus, Lælius Decimus, and Q. Granins Præco.
tgt_text.4392: He had a violent quarrel with C. Cælius, for acquitting a man who had libelled him.
tgt_text.4393: He is said to have lived under Velia, where the temple of Victory afterwards stood, in a house built at the public expense for the son of king Antiochus when hostage at Rome.
tgt_text.4396: He made a voyage to Sicily, but for what cause, or at what period of his life, is not stated.
tgt_text.4397: His closing years were spent at Naples, whither he retired to avoid, as some think, the effects of the hatred of those whom his Satire had offended;
tgt_text.4398: and here he died, B. C. 103, in his forty-sixth year, and was honoured, according to Eusebius, with a public funeral.
tgt_text.4399: He had a faithful slave named Metrophanes, whose honesty and fidelity he rewarded by writing an epitaph for his tomb, quoted by Martial as an instance of antique and rugged style of writing, xi. Ep. 90. “ Carmina nulla probas molli quw limite currant, Sed quæ per salebras altaque saxa caduut:
tgt_text.4400: Et tibi Mæonio res carmine major habetur Luceili Columella heic situ' Metrophaues."
tgt_text.4401: The name of his mistress is said to have been Collyra, to whom the sixteenth book of his Satires was inscribed.
tgt_text.4402: He wrote thirty books of Satires, of which the first twenty and the last are in Heroic metre.
tgt_text.4403: The other nine in Iambics or Trochaics.
tgt_text.4404: He is not to be confounded with a comic poet of the same name, mentioned by the Scholiast on Horace and by Fulgentius.
tgt_text.4405: Such is the traditional, and for a long time currently-believed, story of Lucilius' life.
tgt_text.4406: The greater accuracy, or greater scepticism, of modern scholars has called into question nearly every one of these meagre facts.
tgt_text.4407: Even the method of spelling his name has been a subject of fierce controversy.
tgt_text.4408: In the best manuscripts, especially those of Horace, Cicero, and Nonius Marcellus, the name of Lucilius is invariably spelt with one 1.
tgt_text.4409: Yet in spite of this testimony, in order to square with some pre-conceived notions of orthography, the I was doubled by Hadrian Turnebe, Claude de Saumaise, Joseph Scaliger, Lambinus, Jos. Mercer, and Cortius.
tgt_text.4410: The propriety, however, of omitting the second I has been fully established by an appeal to MSS.
tgt_text.4412: and to Varges and ElleDdt the credit is due of successfully restoring the correct mode of spelling.
tgt_text.4414: Museum for 1835, and Ellendt on Cicero de Orat. iii. 43.)Again, his prænomen is by some stated to be Lucius;
tgt_text.4415: whereas, not to mention others, Cicero and Quintilian always speak of him asCaius.
tgt_text.4416: But far more serious doubts, and with great probability, have been cast upon the dates assigned by S. Hieronymus for his birth and death.
tgt_text.4417: Bayle, in his Dictionary, was the first to suggest them ;
tgt_text.4418: and they were taken up and urged with great zeal and learning by Van Heusde, (in his Studia Critica in C. Lucilium Poetam, 1842,) who accused Jerome of negligence and incorrectness in the dates he assigns to many other events:
tgt_text.4419: e. g. the overthrow of Numantia, the deaths of Plautus, Horace, Catullus, Lucretius, and Livius the tragedian, and the birth of Messala Corvinus.
tgt_text.4420: The charge against the chronographer has been repeated, and with some show of truth, by Ritschel in the Rhenish Museum, 1843.
tgt_text.4421: Van Heusde's line of argument is simply this, that the dates of Hieron.
tgt_text.4422: are inconsistent with what Horace and Velleius say of Lucilius, and with what the poet says of himself,-that it is absurd to suppose that a lad of fifteen could have served as an eques;
tgt_text.4423: or that so young a person would have been admitted to such intimate familiarity with men like Scipio Africanus and Laelius ;
tgt_text.4424: and that at the time of Scipio's death, when, as it is said, Lucilius had already gained a great reput­ ation as a Satirist, he could have been barely over nineteen years old;
tgt_text.4425: that if be had died at the age of forty-six, Horace would not have applied to him the epithet " Senex,"—that the year of his birth must be therefore carried back at least six years, and his death assigned to a much later period, as he mentions the Leges Liciniæ and Calpurnia, passed some years after the time fixed by Hieron.
tgt_text.4428: Notwith­ standing the distinctness of this statement of S. Hieronymus, and the ingenuity with which many writers have attempted to explain it, it appears to me utterly irreconcilable with facts."
tgt_text.4430: Clinton also says,1 (F. H. ann. B. c. 103,) " The expression of Horace, Sat. II.
tgt_text.4431: i. 34, by whom Lucilius is called ‘ Senex,' implies that he lived to a later period.
tgt_text.4432: "Such are the principal objections to the common accounts.
tgt_text.4433: Of those who hold their accuracy, and endeavour to explain away the difficulties attaching to them, the chief are Varges and Gerlach.
tgt_text.4434: The principal points will be taken in the order in which they occur.
tgt_text.4435: With regard to the first, Varges shows, in opposition to Bayle, that it was the custom for young Romans to serve long before the legal age, either voluntarily, that they might apply themselves sooner to civil matters, by getting over their period of military service ;
tgt_text.4436: or compulsorily, to supply the waste of soldiers caused by the incessant wars in which Rome was engaged.
tgt_text.4437: Hence the necessity for the law of C. Gracchus to prevent enlistment under the age of seventeen.
tgt_text.4438: (νεώτερονἐτω̃ν ἐπτακαίδεκα μὴ καταλέγεσθαι στρατιώτην.) Cf. Liv. xxv. 5. Duk. ad Liv. xxvi. 25.
tgt_text.4439: As the equestrian service was the more honourable, it was probably conceded to Lucilius on ac­ count of bis gentle birth and early promise.
tgt_text.4440: Gerlach thinks that Tibullus2 was only thirteen when he accompanied M. Valerius Messalla Corvinus in his Aquitanian campaign.
tgt_text.4441: Now Tibullus was only of squestrian family.
tgt_text.4442: There is no difficulty therefore in supposing that Lucilius, who was of senatorian family, might have served as eques at the age of fifteen.
tgt_text.4444: As to the fact of Scipio and Lælius admitting him to their inti­ mate friendship at so early an age, a parallel may be found in the case of Archias the poet.
tgt_text.4445: Besides, Scipio and Lælius were the most likely men to discover and to foster the early talent of the young poet.
tgt_text.4446: For the fact of the intimacy we have the testimony of Horace, Sat. II.
tgt_text.4447: i. 71, " Quin ubi se a vulgo et scena in secreta remorant Virtus Scipiadæ et mitis sapientia Lælî Nugari cum illo et discincti ludere, donee Decoqueretur olus, soliti."
tgt_text.4448: On which the commentator says, " That the three were on such in­ timate terms, that on one occasion Lælius was running round the sofas in the Triclinium, while Lucilius was chasing him with a twisted towel to hit him with."
tgt_text.4449: This story agrees exactly with the description given by Cicero' (de Orat. ii.
tgt_text.4450: 6) of the conduct of Scipio and Lælius, who speaks of their retiring together to the country- house of the former, and to have descended, for the relaxation of their minds, to the most childish amusements, such as gathering shells on the shore of Caieta.
tgt_text.4451: Who would be more likely than such men as these to be captivated by the precocious wit and pun­ gent sarcasm of a sprightly lad ?
tgt_text.4452: Again, the character of Lucilius' compositions admits of eminence at an earlier period of life than the other branches of poetry.
tgt_text.4453: And yet Catullus and Propertius, not to mention many others, attained great eminence as poets at a very early age ;
tgt_text.4454: certainly long before their twentieth year.
tgt_text.4455: The Satiric poetry of Lucilius depending more on a keen per­ ception of the ludicrous, and shrewd observation of passing events and the foibles of individuals, would more readily win approbation at an early age, than compositions whose excellence would consist in the display of judgment, knowledge of the world, and elaborate finish.
tgt_text.4456: There is therefore no reason to suppose that his talent may not, like that of Cicero, have been developed at an early age, and having come under the notice, might have won the approbation, of men of such character in private life as Scipio and Lælius are re­ ported to have been.
tgt_text.4457: But Horace calls him " senex," ii. Sat. 28, seq. " Ille (Lucilius) velut fidis arcana sodalibus olim Credebat libris :
tgt_text.4458: neque si male cesserat, unquam Decurrens alio, neque si bene, quo fit ut omnis Votiva pateat veluti descripta tabella Vita Senis—"
tgt_text.4460: nothing can be more loose and vague than the employment by Roman writers of terms relating to the different periods of human life :
tgt_text.4461: e. g. " puer, adolescentulus, adolescens, juvenis, senex."
tgt_text.4462: We have seen that Tibullus at the age of forty may be called "juvenis."
tgt_text.4463: Hannibal, at the age of forty-four, (i. e. two years younger than Lucilius at his death,) calls himself senex.
tgt_text.4464: (Cf. Liv. xxx. 30, compared with c. 28, and Crevier's note.)2 So Persius (Sat. i. 124) calls Aristophanes " prægrandis senex," though, as Ranke shows in his Life, (p. xc.,) he was not of great age.
tgt_text.4465: We might add that Horace himself uses the phrase, " poetarum seni­ eram turba," (i. Sat. x. 67,) as equivalent to priorum.
tgt_text.4466: In the fourth Fragment of the twentieth book, Lucilius mentions the Calpurnian Law. " Calpurnî sævam legem Pisoni' reprendi Eduxique animam in primoribu' naribus."
tgt_text.4467: This Van Heusde holds to be the Lex Calpurnia, de ambitu, passed by C. Calpurnius Piso, when consul, A. U. c. 687, B. c. 67, at which time Lucilius would have been eighty-one years old.
tgt_text.4468: But there was another Lex Calpurnia, de pecuniis repetundis, passed by L. Calpurnius Piso, tribune, in A. u. c. 604, n. c. 150.
tgt_text.4469: Van Heusde says the former must be meant, because Lucilius applies to it the epithet sceva, and Cicero (pro Muræna, c. 46) also styles it "seve­ rissime scriptam."
tgt_text.4470: He explains the second line of the Fragment to mean, that Lucilius " all but paid the penalty of death for his ani­ madversions of the law," but these words more correctly imply the fierce snorting of an angry man."
tgt_text.4471: So Pers. Sat. v. 91, "Ira cadat naso."
tgt_text.4472: Varro, R. R. ii. 3, 5, " Spiritum naribus ducere."
tgt_text.4473: Mart. vi. Ep. 64, " Rabido nec perditus ore fumantem nasum vivi tentaveris ursi."
tgt_text.4474: And any law whatever would be naturally termed "sæva" by him who came under the influence of it.
tgt_text.4475: In the 132nd of the Fragmenta Incerta, we have (quoted from A. Cell. Noct. Att. ii. 24) these words, " Legem vitemus Licini."
tgt_text.4476: The object of this law was to give greater sanction to the provisions of the Lex Fannia, a sumptuary law, which had become nearly obsolete.
tgt_text.4477: If passed by P. Licinius Crassus Dives Lusitanicus, when consul, it must be referred to the year A. U. c. 657, B. c. 97, six years after the supposed date of Lucilius' death.
tgt_text.4478: But there is no reason why this law should not have been passed by Licinius when tribune or præto?-, as well as when consul;
tgt_text.4479: probably during his prætorship, as nearer the consulship, though Pighius, (Annal. iii. 122,) though without giving any authority, assigns it to his tri­ buneship.
tgt_text.4480: The Orchian Law was passed by C. Orchius when tribune.
tgt_text.4481: The Fannian and many other sumptuary laws were passed by prætors or tribunes.
tgt_text.4482: The argument therefore derived from the law having been passed by Licinius, when consul, falls to the ground.
tgt_text.4483: Allowing, however, that Lucilius was alive during the consul­ ship of Licinius, we have the incidental, and therefore more valua­ ble, testimony of Cicero that he must have died very shortly after.
tgt_text.4484: In his " De Oratore," he introduces the speakers in the Dialogue quoting Lucilius, as one evidently not very recently dead.
tgt_text.4485: Now this imaginary Dialogue is supposed to have taken place B. c. 91.
tgt_text.4486: To the first book there is said to have been annexed an Epistle to L. AElius Stilo, the friend of the poet, to whom in all probability this book was dedicated.
tgt_text.4488: We know from a note of Servius on the tenth book of the Æneid, (1. 104,) that the subject was a council of gods held to de­ liberate on the fortune of the Roman state ;
tgt_text.4489: the result of the conference being, that nothing but the death of certain obnoxious individuals could possibly rescue the city from plunging headlong into ruin.
tgt_text.4490: It is a kind of parody on the council of Celestials held in the first book of the Odyssey, to discuss the propriety of the return of Ulysses to Greece:
tgt_text.4491: and as Homer represents Neptune, the great enemy of Ulysses, to have been absent from the meeting, so here (Fr. 2) we find an allusion to some previous council, at which Jupiter, by the machinations of Juno, (Fr. 15,) was not present.
tgt_text.4492: Virgil, as Servius says, borrowed the idea of his discussion be­ tween Venus, Juno, and Jupiter, from this book;
tgt_text.4493: only he translated the language of Lucilius into a type more suited to the dignity of Heroic verse.
tgt_text.4494: Lucilius's council begin with discussing the affairs of mankind at large, and theu proceed to consider the best method of prolonging the Roman state, (Fr. 5,) which has no greater enemies than its own corrupt and licentious morals, and the wide-spreading evils of avarice and luxury.
tgt_text.4495: But amidst the growing vices which undermined the state, must especially be reckoned the study of a spurious kind of philosophy, of rhetoric, and logic, which not only was the cause of universal indolence and neglect of all serious duties, but also led men to lay snares to entrap their neighbours.
tgt_text.4496: (Fr. inc. 2.) A fair instance of these sophistical absurdities is given (Fr. inc. 12) ;
tgt_text.4497: and the doctrine of the Stoics, to which Horace alludes, (i. Sat. iii. 124,) is also ridiculed.
tgt_text.4499: The pernicious effects of gold are then described, as destructive of all honesty, good faith, and every religious principle (Fr. inc. 39—47) ;
tgt_text.4500: the result of which is, that the state is fast sinking into helpless ruin. (Fr. inc. 50.)
tgt_text.4501: Nor are the evils of luxury less baleful.
tgt_text.4502: (Fr. 19—21.)All this discussion, in the previous conference, had been nugatory on account of the absence of Jupiter, and the divisions that had arisen amongst the gods themselves.
tgt_text.4503: In this debate Neptune had taken a very considerable part, since we hear that, discussing some very abstruse and difficult point, he said, it could not be cleared up, even though Orcus were to permit Carneades himself to revisit earth.
tgt_text.4504: (Fr. 8.) Apollo also was probably one of the speakers, and expressed a particular dislike to his cognomen of " the Beautiful." (Fr. inc. 144.)
tgt_text.4505: Perhaps all the gods but Jove (Fr. 3) had been present;
tgt_text.4506: but as they could not agree, the whole matter was re­ ferred to Jupiter;
tgt_text.4507: who, expressing his vexation that he was not present at the first meeting, blames some and praises others.
tgt_text.4509: The cause of his absence was probably the same as that described (Iliad xiv. 307—327) by Homer;
tgt_text.4510: which passage Lueilius probably meant to ridicule.
tgt_text.4512: The result of the deliberation is a determination on the part of the gods, that the only way to save the Roman state is by requiring the expiatory sacrifice of the most flagitious and impious amongst the citizens;
tgt_text.4513: and the three fixed upon are, P. Cornelius Lentulus Lupus, L. Papirius Carbo, and C. Hostilius Tubulus.
tgt_text.4514: (To this book may perhaps also be referred Fr. inc. 2, 46, 61, 63.)

tgt_text.4520: and first of all will give each of them, as they arrive, the bellies of thunny and heads of acharne.14 ...15 .... so that I could compare [the embraces] of Leda daughter of Thestius, and the spouse of Ixion.16

tgt_text.4522: 21 Velvets and double piles, soft with their thick naps.22 .. that, like an angry cur, speaks plainer than a man.23 .. the common herd stupidly look for a knot in a bulrush.24 ... and legions serve for pay.25 .... quote prodigies, elephants.26 ... ladles and ewers.

tgt_text.4526: On the subject of this book the commentators differ;
tgt_text.4527: some supposing that it was directed against luxury and effeminacy.
tgt_text.4528: But the avarice and licentiousness of the times form a considerable portion of the writings of Lucilius, and there are very few of his Satires in which these are not in­ cidentally glanced at.

tgt_text.4554: We have not only much more ample and satisfactory information respecting the subject of this Satire from ancient writers, but the Fragments which have come down to us give sufficient evidence that their statements are correct.
tgt_text.4555: It is the description of a journey which Lucilius took from Rome to Capua, and thence to the Straits of Messina;
tgt_text.4556: with an account of some of the halting-places on his route, and incidents of travel.
tgt_text.4557: Besides this, which was the main subject, he indulged by the way in a little pleasing raillery against some of his contemporaries, Ennius, Pacuvius, Cæcilius, and Terence, according to the old Scholiast.
tgt_text.4558: This Satire formed the model from which Horace copied his Journey to Brundusium, i. Sat. v.
tgt_text.4559: The special points of imitation will be seen in the notes ;
tgt_text.4560: from which it will appear that the particular incidents mentioned by Horace, are probably fictitious.
tgt_text.4561: As to the journey itself, Varges and Gerlach are both of opinion that it was a real one, and undertaken solely for purposes of pleasure ;
tgt_text.4562: as it was not unusual for the wealthier Romans of that day to travel into Campania, or even to Lucania, and as far as the district of the Bruttii.
tgt_text.4564: These journeys were occasionally performed on foot:
tgt_text.4565: as we hear of Cato travelling on foot through the different cities of Italy, bearing his own arms, and attended only by a single slave, who carried his baggage and libation-cup for sacrificing.
tgt_text.4566: But Lucilius probably on this occasion had his hackney, (canterius,) like Horace, which carried not only his master's saddle-bags, but himself also.
tgt_text.4568: It is not quite clear whether the scene described at Capua was a gladiatorial exhibition, or merely a drunken brawl that took place in the streets, from which one of the parties came very badly off.
tgt_text.4569: Several of the " uncertain Fragments " may be fairly referred to this book;

tgt_text.4802: The old Scholiast, in his Life of Persius, tells us that " after he had quitted school, and the instruction of his tutors, he was so much struck with the tenth book of the Satires of Lucilius, that he was seized with a vehement desire of writing Satire, and immediately applied himself to the imitation of this book, and after first detracting from his own merits, proceeded to disparage the poetical attempts of others."
tgt_text.4803: Van Heusde supposes that the book contained a detailed account of the life of Lucilius;
tgt_text.4804: and hence the saying of the Scholiast, that " the whole life of Lucilius was as distinctly known as if it had been portrayed in pictures."
tgt_text.4805: (So Horace says, Sat. II. i. 30,) " Quo fit ut omnis Votivà pateat veluti descripta tabella Vita senis."
tgt_text.4806: He conjectures the difference between the subjects of the ninth and tenth books to have been this :
tgt_text.4807: that in the ninth, Lucilius criticised the ignorance and corrected the mistakes of the Librarii;
tgt_text.4808: i. e. those who copied the com­ positions of the poets, only incidentally, and by the way, touching on the poets themselves.
tgt_text.4809: Whereas the tenth was intended directly as an attack upon the poets who preceded him.
tgt_text.4810: Jahn, in his prolegomena on Persius, imagines this imitation of the tenth book to have been carried further than we are perhaps justified in assuming ;

tgt_text.5084: The book begins, therefore, with a conversation between the poet and a friend, when the various points at issue are brought forward and refuted.

tgt_text.5087: He then defends his choice of the particular branch of poetry which he has adopted, and proves that his satiric view is to be attributed to no arrogance, self-sufficiency, or malevolence, or envy towards his fellow-men ;
tgt_text.5088: that he himself is possessed of a certain evenness of temper, neither elated by prosperity nor depressed by adversity.
tgt_text.5089: The result of this temperament is an openness of heart, and frankness of disposition, which leads him to form friendships rapidly, without that cautious circumspection which commonly attends men of less equable tone of mind.
tgt_text.5090: This peculiar dis­ position of mind is alto one which, extending to itself no indulgence for any frailty, is but little inclined to overlook the weaknesses of others, but impartially corrects the failings of itself and others:
tgt_text.5091: whereas the more common character of mankind is to be indulgently blind to those faults to which they are themselves inclined, and severely critical of the imperfec­ tions of their neighbours.
tgt_text.5092: While others, again, make it their whole study hypocritically to conceal their own defects.
tgt_text.5093: He concludes with a sentiment which Horace has borrowed and enlarged upon, that whereas no perfec­ tion can be expected in this life, he is to be accounted to have arrived most nearly at the wished-for goal, who is disfigured by the fewest defects;
tgt_text.5094: and since all human affairs are at the best but frail and fleeting, it is a charac­ teristic of wisdom out of evils to choose the least.

tgt_text.5173: He then describes one of these scenes of dissipation;
tgt_text.5174: and shows how young men, once entangled in the snares of their worthless paramours, not only become lost to every principle of virtue and sense of shame, but are so completely enslaved and enthralled by their passions, that they are able to refuse no­ thing, however unworthy of them, which is exacted by their tyrannical mistresses.

tgt_text.5219: 73Most of the commentators seem to be agreed that the subject of this book was “matrimonial life."
tgt_text.5220: Mercer considers that it contained an altercation between a married couple, in which the lady strenuously refuses to submit to the lawful authority of her husband.
tgt_text.5221: Van Heusde says that in it were depicted the miseries of married life generally;
tgt_text.5222: especially of those husbands who are so devoted to their wives, that they surrender the reins of govern­ ment into the hands of those, for whom the law compels them to provide subsistence, not only at the expense of their own personal labour, but also at the risk of life itself:
tgt_text.5223: the only return which they receive as an equiva­ lent from the hands of their wives, being opprobrious language, ill-temper, haughty exaction, treachery, and unfaithfulness to the marriage-bed.
tgt_text.5224: In addition to this, Gerlach thinks that in this, his last book, Lucilius reca­ pitulated the subjects of his previous Satires;
tgt_text.5225: and consequently many Fragments are assigned to this book, which might easily be inserted in others.

tgt_text.0: Quiotus Horatius Flaccus naquit à Venouse, en Àpulie, d’un père affranchi, qui vivait d’un bien et d’un emploi médiocres.
tgt_text.1: Le père d’Horace se montra jaloux de développer l’heureux naturel de sou fils par une éducation libérale;
tgt_text.2: il s’épuisa en sacrifices pour que ce jeune homme, d’un génie précoce, pût aller chercher la science dans les lieux où elle était enseignée avec le plus d’éclat, comme s’il eût été de race équestre ou patricienne.
tgt_text.3: Horace fit à Rome ses premières études;
tgt_text.4: et, pins tard, lorsqu’il n’était encore âgé que de vingt ans, il se rendit à Athènes, où il étudia les lettres grecques avec cette foule de jeunes hommes distingués que Rome envoyait chaque année dans cette cité savante.
tgt_text.5: Malgré son goût pour la poésie et les jouissances de la paix, il se laissa entraîner dans le tourbillon de la guerre civile, et, tout jeune, tout fils d’affranchi qu’il était, il reçut de Brutus le commandement d’une de ces légions qui succombèrent à Philippes sous la fortune d’Octave.
tgt_text.6: Puni de sa participation à cette guerre par la confiscation de son modique patrimoine, et, plus tard, amnistié, il vint à Rome, où ses vers lui concilièrent une foule d’admirateurs et de protecteurs puissants :
tgt_text.7: il obtint la faveur spéciale d’Auguste, qui entretenait avec lui une correspondance familière.
tgt_text.8: Mais l’homme dont le patronage et l’amitié contribuèrent le plus à sa fortune et à son bien-être, fut Mécène, noble romain, dont la maison était le rendez-vous de tout ce que la ville impériale renfermait d’hommes éclairés, d’orateurs, de poêtes, d’historiens de premier ordre.
tgt_text.9: Il en reçut des témoignages de bienveillance et d'estime dont le poëte se montra reconnaissant tonte sa vie.
tgt_text.10: Horace mourut à, l’àge de cinquante-sept ans, l'an 746 de la fondation de Rome, et 9 avant notre ère.
tgt_text.11: Il fut enterré à côté du tombeau de Mécène.A MÉCÈNE.
tgt_text.12: Descendant des rois', toi dont l'appui fait mon bonheur et ma gloire, Mécène, on voit des hommes qui mettent leur ambition à se couvrir de la poussière d’un cirque;
tgt_text.13: et, quand leur roue brûlante a évité la borne, une fois la palme obtenue,
tgt_text.14: Jupiter lui-même n’est plus au-dessus d’eux.
tgt_text.15: L’un est heureux si la faveur d’un peuple inconstant s’empresse de l’élever aux honneurs suprêmes;
tgt_text.16: l'autre, s'il entasse dans ses greniers toutes les moissons de la Libye.
tgt_text.17: Tel se contente de cultiver le champ de ses pères;
tgt_text.18: et tous les trésors d’Attale 2 ne l’arracheraient pas à sa charrue, pour aller, matelot tremblant, traverser le plus humble détroit sur le meilleur navire.
tgt_text.19: Que le vent d’Afrique vienne a lutter contre les flots, le marchand effrayé vante le repos -et les champs voisins de sa petite ville;
tgt_text.20: mais bientôt, indocile à souffrir le joug de la pauvreté, il radoube ses vaisseaux maltraités par la tempête.
tgt_text.21: Tel ne hait pas une coupe de vieux Massique 3, et dérobera volontiers aux affaires une partie du jour, couché à l’ombre d’un vert feuillage, ou à la source paisible d'une fontaine sacrée.
tgt_text.22: A d'autres il faut des camps, le son de la trompette mêlé à celui du clairon, et les combats détestés des mères.
tgt_text.23: Le chasseur, oubliant sa jeune épouse, attend sous un ciel glacé que sa meute fidèle ait senti la biche, ou que le sanglier se lance à travers ses toiles.Moi, la couronne de lierre qui orne le front des poëtes me rapproche des dieux :
tgt_text.24: le frais ombrage des bois, les danses légères des nymphes avec les Satyres, me séparent de la foule, pourvu qu’Euterpe n’impose point silence à sa double flûte, et que Polymnie ne refuse pas d’accorder le luth de Lesbos 4.
tgt_text.25: Que Mécèue me compte parmi les maîtres de la lyre, et ma téle ira toucher le ciel.Assez longtemps le père des dieux et des hommes a fait tomber sur la terre et la neige et la grêle;
tgt_text.26: assez longtemps sa main étincelante a foudroyé les temples, et rempli Rome de terreur.
tgt_text.28: ils ont craint le retour de ces temps de colère et de prodiges, où Pyrrha vit avec épouvante Protée chasser les troupeaux de Neptune sur le sommet des montagnes, les poissons s’arrêter dans les branches de l’orme où avait reposé le nid de la colombe, et les daims tremblants nager sur les eaux qui couvraient la terre.Nous avons vu le Tibre, ramenant avec fureur du rivage de la mer ses vagues limoneuses, venir renverser un tombeau royal 2 et le temple de Vesta;
tgt_text.29: quand, trop sensible aux larmes d'une épouse 3, il osa, sans l’aveu de Jupiter, lui promettre une vengeance, et menacer Rome et ses flots.
tgt_text.30: Tu sauras que nous avons aiguisé contre nous le fer qui n’aurait dû frapper que les Partîtes;
tgt_text.31: tu sauras nos combats impies, jeunesse si peu nombreuse, grâce aux fureurs de tes pères!Quel dieu le peuple appellera-t-il au secours de l’empire qui menace ruine?
tgt_text.32: Comment les vierges saintes de Vesta pourrontelles fléchir la Déesse, qui ferme l’oreille à leurs prières?
tgt_text.33: A qui Jupiter donnera-t-il d’expier nos crimes?
tgt_text.34: Viens, il est temps, viens dans une brillante nuée, prophétique Apollon!
tgt_text.35: Ou toi, descends parmi nous, Vénus au doux sourire, autour de qui voltigent les Jeux et les Amours!
tgt_text.36: Ou toi, père des Romains, jette un regard sur ta race oubliée :
tgt_text.37: tes jeux cruels n'ont-ils pas duré trop longtemps, dieu terrible, qui n’aimes que le cri des batailles, l’éclat des armes, et le regard farouche du Marse sur son ennemi sanglant.
tgt_text.38: Mais si c'est toi, dieu ailé, fils de la divine Maia, qui, sous les traits d'un jeune héros, daignes recevoir ici-bas le nom de vengeur de César, ah!
tgt_text.39: demeure longtemps sur la terre pour le bonheur des Romains, et, à la vue de nos crimes, ne fuis pas indigné dans les cieux!
tgt_text.40: Ici, plutòt, jouis de glorieux triomphes;
tgt_text.41: ici, qu’il le soit doux d’être appelé le Père et le Chef de la patrie;
tgt_text.42: et que le coursier du Mède ne foule pas impunément la ferre où tu commandes, César!AU VAISSEAU DE VIRGILE
tgt_text.43: .Puissent la déesse adorée en Chypre, el les frères d'Hélène ces astres radieux, te servir de guides;
tgt_text.44: puisse le roi des Vents les encliaîner tous, et ne livrer tes voiles qu’à celui de l’Apulie, ô vaisseau à qui j’ai confié Virgile 2!
tgt_text.46: déposele sain et sauf au rivage de l’Attique, et conserve, je l’en supplie, la plus chère moitié de moi-même.
tgt_text.47: Celui-là fut sans doute armé d’un triple bronze, qui le premier osa livrer aux flots menaçants une barque fragile, délier le choc impétueux des vents qui se heurtent, et les sinistres Hyades, et la furie du Notus, ce puissant dominateur des mers, qu'il soulève ou calme à son gré.
tgt_text.48: Sous quel aspect la Mort eûtelle pu l'étonner, celui qui vit d’un œil impassible les monstres de l’abîme, et la mer gonflée de courroux, et les écueils tristement fameux de l’Épire?
tgt_text.49: En vain les dieux, dans leur sagesse, ont séparé les mondes par la barrière.de l’Océan;
tgt_text.50: des vaisseaux sacrilèges osent la violer.
tgt_text.51: L’audace humaine aspire à tout, et se jette dans une lutte impie contre les lois divines.
tgt_text.52: L’audace de Prométhée ravit le feu du ciel, pour le donner aux nations;
tgt_text.53: et, après ce larcin fatal, l’horrible Maigreur, les Fièvres brûlantes, une armée de fléaux inconnus s’abattit sur la terre;
tgt_text.54: la Mort, jusque-là si lente et si tardive, précipita ses pas.
tgt_text.55: Sur des ailes que la nature n'a point données à l’homme, Dédale tente le chemin des airs :
tgt_text.56: la bras d’Hercule a forcé l'Achéron.
tgt_text.57: Rien ne parait impossible aux mortels;
tgt_text.58: leur démence attaque le ciel même;
tgt_text.59: et nos crimes ne permettent pas à Jupiter de déposer sa foudre irritée.
tgt_text.60: L’hiver s’adoucit par l’agréable retour du printemps et des Zéphirs;
tgt_text.61: les machines arrachent les navires au sable du rivage 1;
tgt_text.62: le troupeau quitte avec joie son étable, et le laboureur son foyer;
tgt_text.63: le givre ne blanchit plus les prairies.
tgt_text.64: A la clarté de la lune qui se balance sur l’horizon, Vénus conduit le chœur des Nymphes et des Grâces :
tgt_text.65: leurs pieds légers frappent la terre en cadence, tandis que Tardent Vulcain embrase les noirs ateliers des Cyclopes.Mêlons à nos cheveux parfumés le myrte vert et les fleurs que les chauds rayons du soleil font éclore;
tgt_text.66: immolons au dieu Faune, à l'ombre des bois sacrés, une jeune brebis, ou, s’il l’aime mieux, un chevreau.La Mort heurte indifféremment à la chaumière du pauvre et au palais des rois.
tgt_text.67: Heureux Sextius, la vie est courte, et ne nous permet pas un long espoir :
tgt_text.68: bientôt pèsera sur toi la nuit des mânes et des royaumes vides de Pluton.
tgt_text.69: Arrivé là, tu ne pourras plus tirer au sort la royauté des festins, ni contempler avec amour le tendre Lycidas, que nos jeunes Romains dévorent des yeux, et dont la beauté troublera bientôt le cœur des jeunes filles.
tgt_text.70: Quel tendre adolescent, couvert de parfums et de roses, te presse, ô Pyrrha, sous cette grotte voluptueuse?
tgt_text.71: Est-ce pour lui que tu relèves tes blonds cheveux, gracieuse et simple fille?Ah! que de larmes lui coûteront la foi trahie et son bonheur perdu, quand il verra, tristement surpris, les noirs orages troubler cette mer aujourd'hui si calme, où il vogue crédule à tes paroles dorées, heureux de l'espoir que tu seras toujours fidèle, toujours aimante, et sans se douter combien les vents sont trompeurs!
tgt_text.72: Malheur à ceux que ton éclat perfide a sèduit(??)!
tgt_text.73: Pour moi, échappé du naufrage, j'ai suspendu au temple de Neptune un tableau votif et mes vêtements humides 1.C’est à Varius3 de célébrer ton âme intrépide et tes victoires;
tgt_text.74: au cygne de la poésie épique, de chanter tout ce que nos armées et nos flottes ont fait de grand sous tes ordres :
tgt_text.75: un Homère seul doit dire tes actions, et la colère de l'inflexible Achille, et les courses lointaines du rusé Ulysse, et la sanglante maison de Pélops;
tgt_text.76: sujets trop puissants pour mon faible génie.Ma lyre a peur des combats :
tgt_text.77: la muse qui l'inspire et le respect me défendent de flétrir, en y touchant, les lauriers de César et les tiens.
tgt_text.78: Qui peindra dignement Mars revêtu d’acier, Mérion tout poudreux aux champs de Troie, Diomède, avec l’appui de Pallas, luttant contre les dieux?Moi, je chante les festins,· les combats ou la jeune fille menace un amant d'un ongle peu redoutable;
tgt_text.79: je chante, libre aujourd’hui, amoureux demain, toujours fidèle à mon humeur légère.
tgt_text.80: D'autres vanteront Milylène, Rhodes, Éphèse, Corinthe, assise entre deux mers, Thèbes, illustrée par Bacchus, Delphes par Apollon, ou la vallée délicieuse de Tempé.
tgt_text.81: Il en est dont l'unique affaire est de chanter dans un hymne éternel la ville de la chaste Pallas et de se parer le front d’un olivier banal :
tgt_text.82: d’autres, en l'honneur de Jnnon, célèbrent Argos et ses coursiers, Mycèneetses richesses.
tgt_text.83: Pour moi, l'austère Lacédémone, les fertiles campagnes de Larisse, me touchent moins que la grotte où l’Albunée résonne, les cascades de l'Αniο, le bois sacré de Tibur, et ses jardins arrosés de mobiles ruisseaux.Le Notus n'enfante pas d’éternels orages;
tgt_text.84: souvent il chasse les nuées dont le ciel est obscurci :
tgt_text.85: de même, ô Plancus, si tu es sage, il faut chasser la tristesse et oublier dans le vin les agitations de la vie;
tgt_text.86: que tu sois retenu sous la tente, au milieu des camps, ou sous les épais ombrages de Tibur.
tgt_text.87: Vois Teucer obligé de fuir son père et Salamine, il ceint d'un rameau de peuplier ses tempes humides de vin;
tgt_text.88: et comme ses compagnons paraissaient tristes et abattus :
tgt_text.89: « La Fortune sera moins cruelle que mon père, leur dit-il;
tgt_text.90: où elle voudra nous conduire nous irons, mes amis!
tgt_text.93: vous êtes sous les auspices de Teucer.
tgt_text.94: Apollon l’a promis, croyez-le, nous trouverons sur une terre nouvelle une autre Salamine 2.
tgt_text.95: Vous avez subi avec moi de plus rudes épreuves :
tgt_text.97: demain nous reprendrons nos courses sur la vaste mer.
tgt_text.98: »A LYDIE.Lydie, au nom de tous les dieux, dis-moi, je t’en conjure, pourquoi, par ton fatal amour, t’empresser de perdre Sybaris?
tgt_text.99: Pourquoi fuit-il aujourd’hui le champ de Mars, dont il bravait la poussière et le soleil?
tgt_text.100: Pourquoi ne le voit-on plus, en habit de guerre, au milieu des jeunes Romains de son âge, dompter avec le mors un coursier gaulois?
tgt_text.101: Il craint les eaux du Tibre, et se garde avec horreur de l’huile des athlètes, comme du venin de la vipère.
tgt_text.102: Où sont les armes pesantes dont il chargeait son bras, le disque, le javelot, qu’il était fier de lancer au delà du but?
tgt_text.103: Pourquoi se tient-il caché, comme autrefois Achille, aux approches des tristes funérailles de Troie, de peur que l'habit de son sexe ne l’entraînât au milieu du carnage et des bataillons troyens?Vois comme une neige épaisse blanchit la cime élevée du Soracle 1, les arbres fatigués fléchissent sous le poids des frimais;
tgt_text.104: et les eaux, saisies par une âpre gelée, ont suspendu leur cours.
tgt_text.105: Chasse le froid, cher Thaliarque, fais-nous un large feu dans ton foyer, et ne crains pas de toucher à ton vieux vin.
tgt_text.107: ils feront tomber les vents qui se combattent sur une mer orageuse, et la tempête cessera de tourmenter les grands cyprès et les vieux ormes.Ne t'inquiète pas du lendemain;
tgt_text.108: mets à profit chaque jour que le destin t’accorde.
tgt_text.109: Aujourd'hui jeune et beau, tandis que la vieillesse chagrine est encore loin de toi, ne méprise ni les danses ni les amours :
tgt_text.110: aujourd'hui les promenades au Champde-Mars et sous les portiques, les mystérieux rendez-vous, le doux murmure des entretiens du soir, le rire charmant qui trahit la jeune fille dans le coin obscur où elle se cache, et les gages d’amour ravis à un bras ou à une main doucement rebelle.
tgt_text.111: Dieu de l'éloquence, petit-fils d'Atlas, toi qui sus adoucir, par le charme de la parole et des arts, les mœurs farouches des premiers hommes;
tgt_text.112: je te chante, Ô Mercure, messager de l'Olympe, père de la lyre, dieu rusé, dont rien n’arrête les joyeux, larcins!Encore enfant, tu avais dérobé les génisses d’Apollon 2? « Rends-les moi! » disait-il d’une voix menaçante;
tgt_text.113: tout à coup son carquois disparaît, et le dieu ne put s’empêcher de rire.
tgt_text.114: Sous ta conduite, l’opulent Priam sortit d'ilion avec ses tré sors, et, trompant la vigilance des Atrides, traversa les feux thessaliens et le camp ennemi de Troie.Tu déposes les âmes pieuses dans les demeures fortunées, et ta verge d’or rassemble l'essaim léger des ombres;
tgt_text.115: ministre aimé de tous les dieux, au ciel et dans les enfers.Ne cherche pas à savoir, malgré les dieux, quel terme ils ont fixé à mes jours et aux tiens, Leuconoé;
tgt_text.116: et ne le demande plus aux calculs des astrologues.
tgt_text.117: Qu’il vaut bien mieux attendre et se soumettre au sort!
tgt_text.118: Que Jupiter ajoute encore à tes années, ou qu’il borne leur cours à cet hiver orageux qui fatigue les flots contre leurs barrières de rochers;
tgt_text.119: sois sage, filtre tes vins, et mesure l’espoir à la courte durée de la vie.
tgt_text.120: Tandis que nous parlons, le temps jaloux a fui :
tgt_text.121: cueille la fleur du jour et ne crois pas au lendemain.
tgt_text.122: Quel héros, quel demi-dieu va célébrer ta lyre ou ta.flûte sonore, ô Clio?
tgt_text.123: Quel dieu dont l’écho se plaise à répéter le nom sur les verts sommets de l'Hélicon ou sur le Pinde, ou sur l’Hœmus couvert de neige, et d’où l’on villes forêts descendre à la voix d’Orphée, quand le fils de Calliope, inspiré par sa mère, suspendait les fleuves impétueux, les vents rapides, et que la puissante harmonie de ses accords animait les chênes?Suivant l’usage antique, chantons d’abord Jupiter, le roi des dieux et des hommes, le maître absolu de la terre et des flots, qui gouverne le monde et le cours varié des saisons :
tgt_text.124: rien n’est au-dessus de lui, rien ne lui ressemble, rien ne le supplée.
tgt_text.125: Après lui, mais de loin, Pallas occupe la première place.Salut, intrépide Baechus, et toi, chaste Diane, redoutable aux monstres des forêts, et toi, Phébus, dieu terrible, aux flèches inévitables!Je veux chanter Alcide et les deux fils de Léda :
tgt_text.126: à l’un, la gloire du ceste;
tgt_text.128: Dès que leur blanche étoile a brillé aux yeux des matelots, l'onde soulevée retombe au pied des rochers, les vents se taisent, les nuées fuient, et la vague menaçante rentre, à leur commandement, dans le sein des mers.Chanterai-je après eux Romulus, et le règne paisible de Numa, et l'orgueil brisé de Tarquin, et l'héroïsme de Caton mourant?
tgt_text.129: Mais Régulus, Scaurus, Paul-Émile 1, noble cœur, qui dédaigna de vivre après la victoire d'Annibal, à vous les chants de gloire et de reconnaissance du poète;
tgt_text.130: à vous aussi, Fabricius, Camille, rude et austère Curius, héros formés à la dure école de la pauvreté, sous l'humble toit et dans le modeste héritage de vos pères!
tgt_text.131: Elle croît de jour en jour, comme un jeune arbre par le lent progrès des années, la gloire de Marcellus 2 :
tgt_text.132: l’astre des Jules brille entre tous, comme la lune parmi les feux que son éclat fait pâlir.Père et conservateur du genre humain, fils de Saturne, c'est à toi que les destins ont confié la grandeur de César :
tgt_text.133: que César soit ton second sur la terre!
tgt_text.134: Quand il aura dompté le Parthe qui ose menacer l'Italie, et le Scythe, et l'Indien, voisins des lieux où naît l'Aurore, soumis à toi seul, que ses lois fassent le bonheur du monde :
tgt_text.135: toi, sur ton char tonnant, tu ébranleras l'Olympe, et tu lanceras contre l'impie tes foudres vengeurs!A LYDIE.Ah!
tgt_text.136: Lydie, cesse de louer devant moi Télèphe au cou de rose, Télèphe au bras d'ivoire!
tgt_text.137: Je sens alors la colère gronder dans mon cœur;
tgt_text.140: une larme furtive roule sur ma joue et trahit les feux secrets dont je suis lentement dévoré.
tgt_text.142: quand je vois tes blanches épaules honteusement meurtries par lui, dans la colère de l'ivresse;
tgt_text.143: tes lèvres, où sa dent a imprimé des marques cruelles de son amour!
tgt_text.144: Non, si tu veux m'écouter, ne te fie pas au barbare dont les baisers déchirent cette bouche délicieuse, où Vénusa répandu ses plus doux parfums.
tgt_text.145: Heureux, trois fois heureux, ceux qu'unit un lien indissoluble, que de tristes querelles n'arrachent pas l'un à l’autre, et que la mort seule vient trop tôt séparer.A LA RÉPUBLIQUE.O vaisseau!
tgt_text.146: de nouveaux orages vont le reporter sur les mers.
tgt_text.149: Ne vois-tu pas tes flancs dépouillés de rames, ton mât demibrisé par le vent, les antennes qui gémissent?
tgt_text.150: Sans cordages, pourras-tu soutenir l’effort redoublé des vagues?
tgt_text.151: Pas une de tes voiles qui ne soit en lambeaux;
tgt_text.152: pas un dieu que tu puisses invoquer dans une nouvelle détresse I Jadis pin altier, noble fils des forêts, ne vante pas une vaine origine et un vain nom :
tgt_text.153: les peintures de la poupe ne rassurent point le pilote effrayé.
tgt_text.154: Si tu ne veux être le jouet des vents, prends garde!
tgt_text.155: O toi, objet naguère de ma douleur inquiète, aujourd’hui de mes vœux et de mes soucis, évite les brillants récifs des Cyclades!PRÉDICTION DE NÉRÉEL’hôte perfide de Ménélas, le ravisseur d’Hélène, la traînait avec lui de mers en mers 1 quand Nérée fit peser sur les vents un fatal repos, pour annoncer les terribles secrets de l’avenir.« Malheur à loi!
tgt_text.156: celle que lu conduis à Ilion, toute la Grèce en armes viendra la redemander, après avoir juré de briser des nœuds impies et le sceptre antique de Priam.
tgt_text.158: quels flots de sueur inondent les combattants et les coursiers I Quel vent de mort tu soulèves contre la race de Dardanus!
tgt_text.159: Déjà Pallas apprête son casque, son égide, son char et sa fureur.« En vain, fier de l'appui de Vénus, tu parfumeras ta chevelure, tu charmeras les femmes par tes chants voluptueux et les lâches accords de ta lyre :
tgt_text.160: en vain, couché dans les bras d’Hélène, tu fuiras les lourds javelots!
tgt_text.161: les flèches du Grélois, le bruit des batailles, et la poursuite impétueuse d’Ajax :
tgt_text.162: un jour, mais trop tard, hélas!
tgt_text.163: tu traîneras dans la poussière et dans le sang tes cheveux adultères.« Ne vois-tu pas derrière toi Ulysse, le fléau de ta patrie?
tgt_text.164: Ne vois-tu pas Nestor qui te presse, et l’intrépide Teucer, et Sthénélus, aussi brave qu’habile à diriger un char?
tgt_text.166: Mais voici le fils de Tydée, plus terrible encore que son père, qui brûle de t'atteindre!
tgt_text.167: Et toi, comme le cerf oublie le pâturage pour fuir Je loup qu’il aperçoit au loin dans le vallon, tu fuis haletant, éperdu.
tgt_text.168: Est-ce là ce que tu avais promis à ton Hélène?«
tgt_text.169: La colère d’Achille reculera le jour fatal à Ilion et aux Troyennes :
tgt_text.171: encore quelques hivers, et le feu des Grecs dévorera les palais de Bergame.
tgt_text.172: »O toi, d’une mère si belle, fille plus belle encore, je t’abandonne mes coupables ïambes :
tgt_text.173: ordonne, et qu’ils soient consumés par la flamme, ou ensevelis dans les flots.Non, Cybèle, non, dans leurs sanctuaires, Bacchus et Apollon n’agitent pas le cœur du prêtre inspiré, comme la sombre colère;
tgt_text.174: elle secoue l’âme, telle que les coups redoublés du corybante » sur l'airain sonore :
tgt_text.175: rien ne l’intimide, ni le fer, ni la flamme, ni la mer féconde en naufrages, ni Jupiter lui-même avec les terribles éclats de son tonnerre.
tgt_text.176: On dit que Prométhée, forcé d'ajouter au limon primitif une parcelle de chacun des animaux, mit dans notre sein l'aveugle furie du lion.
tgt_text.177: La colère précipita Thyeste 2 dans un abîme de malheurs :
tgt_text.178: c'est par elle que tant de villes superbes ont péri, et que le vainqueur fil passer sur leurs murs le soc insolent de la charrue.
tgt_text.180: moi aussi, au temps heureux de la jeunesse, je connus cette fièvre, et je fus entraîné dans mou délire à de sanglants ïambes.
tgt_text.181: Aujourd’hui je veux faire succéder la paix àla guerre :
tgt_text.182: ces vers injurieux, je les rétracte;
